questions.stem: Standard 8.02 (Informed Consent to Research) requires that psychologists conducting research inform participants about which of the following at minimum?

options.text: Only the hypothesis of the study
The purpose of the research, expected duration, procedures, right to decline or withdraw, and foreseeable risks
Only the risks and benefits of participation
Only the procedures involved, without mentioning their right to withdraw

questions.explanation: Standard 8.02 specifies that informed consent to research must include: the purpose, expected duration, and procedures; the right to decline or withdraw without penalty; foreseeable consequences of declining or withdrawing; reasonably foreseeable factors that may influence willingness (risks, discomfort, adverse effects); prospective research benefits; limits of confidentiality; incentives; and whom to contact with questions. This is a comprehensive requirement, not limited to any single element.

questions.stem: Under Standard 8.07 (Deception in Research), deception is permissible only when:

options.text: The researcher believes it will make the study more interesting to participants
The study is justified by significant prospective value, non-deceptive alternatives are not feasible, and participants are debriefed afterward
Participants are compensated sufficiently for being deceived
The deception involves only minor aspects of the study design

questions.explanation: Standard 8.07 permits deception only when: (1) the study has significant prospective scientific, educational, or applied value; (2) effective non-deceptive alternative procedures are not feasible; (3) participants are not deceived about research that would cause physical pain or severe emotional distress; and (4) participants are debriefed as early as feasible (Standard 8.08). Compensation alone does not justify deception, and the significance of the aspect being deceived about is not the determining factor.

questions.stem: A psychology professor requires all students in their introductory psychology course to participate in departmental research studies as part of their grade. Under Standard 8.04 (Client/Patient, Student, and Subordinate Research Participants), this is ethically acceptable only if:

options.text: The research is approved by the IRB and involves no risk
Students are given equitable alternative activities to earn the same course credit if they choose not to participate
The professor personally oversees all research involving their students
Students sign a waiver of their right to refuse participation

questions.explanation: Standard 8.04(b) specifically requires that when research participation is a course requirement or an opportunity for extra credit, prospective participants must be given equitable alternative activities. This protects students' right to not participate in research without academic penalty. A waiver of the right to refuse would violate the Ethics Code. IRB approval is necessary but not sufficient, and the professor's oversight does not address the voluntariness concern.

questions.stem: Standard 8.12 (Publication Credit) states that principal authorship and other publication credits should be based on:

options.text: The seniority of the researcher within the department
The relative scientific or professional contributions of the individuals involved
Who secured the funding for the study
Alphabetical order of contributors' last names

questions.explanation: Standard 8.12 specifies that publication credit should reflect the relative scientific or professional contributions of the individuals involved, regardless of their relative status. Faculty advisors should not claim authorship based solely on their supervisory role, and junior researchers who made substantial contributions should receive appropriate credit. Mere position of authority, funding acquisition, or alphabetical ordering do not determine authorship credit.

questions.stem: A researcher conducting a study on obedience to authority uses confederates who appear to be other participants but are actually part of the research team. After the study, several participants report feeling distressed by the experience. Under Standard 8.08 (Debriefing), the researcher's primary obligation is to:

options.text: Send a written summary of the study results after publication
Provide prompt debriefing that explains the true nature of the study, corrects misconceptions, and takes steps to reduce any harm caused by the procedures
Debrief only those participants who request it
Offer additional compensation in lieu of debriefing

questions.explanation: Standard 8.08 requires psychologists to provide debriefing as soon as feasible, during which they explain the nature, results, and conclusions of the research, correct any misconceptions, and take reasonable steps to reduce harm if they become aware that research procedures have caused harm. This obligation applies to all participants, not just those who request it. Debriefing is especially critical when deception was used, as in this scenario. Compensation does not substitute for the debriefing obligation. The debriefing should occur promptly, not delayed until publication.

questions.stem: According to Standard 8.08 (Debriefing), the debriefing process after research participation should include which elements? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Providing participants with information about the nature, results, and conclusions of the research
Correcting any misconceptions that may have arisen from participation
Taking reasonable steps to reduce harm if the psychologist becomes aware that procedures have harmed a participant
Debriefing only those participants who ask for it
Providing debriefing as soon as feasible after participation

questions.explanation: Standard 8.08 requires: providing information about the nature, results, and conclusions (A); correcting misconceptions (B); taking steps to reduce harm if it occurred (C); and providing debriefing promptly (E). Debriefing should be provided to all participants, not just those who request it (D). If debriefing must be delayed (e.g., to protect study integrity), it should still occur as soon as feasible.

questions.stem: Which of the following practices in research would violate Standard 8.10 (Reporting Research Results)? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Fabricating data to support a hypothesis
Reporting non-significant results in a publication
Selectively reporting only significant findings while omitting null results
Falsifying statistical analyses to achieve significance
Correcting errors in published data through a formal correction or retraction

questions.explanation: Violations of Standard 8.10 include: fabricating data (A) is a serious research misconduct; selectively reporting only significant findings (C) is misleading and constitutes a form of data falsification; falsifying statistical analyses (D) is research fraud. Reporting non-significant results (B) is actually good practice that promotes transparency. Correcting published errors (E) is consistent with Standard 8.10(b), which requires psychologists to take reasonable steps to correct errors in published data.

questions.stem: Standard 8.02 (Informed Consent to Research) requires psychologists to inform research participants about several aspects of the study. Which of the following elements are required components of informed consent for research? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: The purpose of the research, expected duration, and procedures
The participant's right to decline or withdraw at any time without penalty
A guarantee that the research will produce beneficial outcomes for the participant
Reasonably foreseeable factors that may influence willingness to participate, such as potential risks or discomfort
Prospective research benefits and limits of confidentiality

questions.explanation: Standard 8.02 specifies that informed consent for research must include: the purpose, expected duration, and procedures (A); the right to decline or withdraw without penalty (B); reasonably foreseeable factors such as risks, discomfort, or adverse effects (D); and prospective benefits and limits of confidentiality (E). Researchers cannot guarantee beneficial outcomes (C); they can describe prospective or potential benefits but must be honest about uncertainty. Additional required elements include whom to contact with questions, incentives for participation, and information about how data will be handled.

questions.stem: Standard 8.14 (Sharing Research Data for Verification) requires psychologists to share data under certain conditions. Which of the following are accurate regarding this standard? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Psychologists must not withhold data on which their conclusions are based from other competent professionals who seek to verify claims through reanalysis
Data sharing is conditioned on protecting the confidentiality of research participants
Psychologists may charge a reasonable fee for the costs of compiling and transmitting data
Psychologists may permanently refuse data sharing requests without justification
Data may be withheld if participants' legal rights concerning proprietary data preclude release

questions.explanation: Standard 8.14 requires data sharing for verification purposes (A) while protecting participant confidentiality (B). Psychologists may charge reasonable costs for data compilation (C) and may withhold data when participants' legal rights or proprietary interests preclude release (E). However, psychologists may not simply refuse data sharing without legitimate justification (D). The standard balances the scientific community's need for verification with participant protections and practical considerations.

questions.stem: Under Standard 8.06 (Offering Inducements for Research Participation), which of the following practices raise ethical concerns? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Offering $500 to homeless individuals for participating in a 30-minute survey about financial stress
Providing course credit with equitable alternatives for non-participants
Offering a $10 gift card for a one-hour study on consumer preferences
Providing free medical screenings as part of a health research study
Offering participation in a lottery for expensive prizes conditional on completing all study phases

questions.explanation: Standard 8.06 requires that psychologists make reasonable efforts to avoid offering excessive or inappropriate inducements that could coerce participation. Offering $500 to homeless individuals (A) is disproportionate and could constitute undue inducement that compromises voluntary participation among a vulnerable population. Lottery prizes conditional on completing all phases (E) creates coercive pressure to continue even if a participant wants to withdraw. Course credit with alternatives (B), modest compensation (C), and medical screenings as part of health research (D) are generally appropriate inducements that do not unduly compromise voluntary participation.

questions.stem: Match each research scenario to the most applicable Standard 8 provision:

rows.text: A researcher tells participants the study is about memory when it actually measures racial bias
A faculty member lists themselves as first author on a student's dissertation publication despite minimal contribution
A researcher destroys original data after publication to protect participant privacy
A researcher offers $500 payment to homeless individuals for participating in a mildly uncomfortable study

columns.text: Standard 8.06: Offering Inducements for Research Participation
Standard 8.14: Sharing Research Data for Verification

questions.explanation: Misrepresenting the study purpose = Standard 8.07 (deception in research). Faculty claiming unwarranted first authorship = Standard 8.12 (publication credit based on relative contributions). Destroying original data = Standard 8.14 (data must be available for verification). Excessive payment to vulnerable populations = Standard 8.06 (inducements should not be coercive, and $500 to homeless individuals may constitute undue inducement that compromises voluntary participation).

questions.stem: Match each research ethics violation to the Standard 8 provision it most directly violates:

rows.text: A researcher publishes the same study in two different journals without disclosing the prior publication
A researcher copies another researcher's literature review into their own manuscript without attribution
A researcher begins data collection at a university hospital before receiving IRB approval
A peer reviewer uses a manuscript under review to advance their own competing research

questions.explanation: Publishing the same study in two journals without disclosure violates Standard 8.13 (Duplicate Publication), which prohibits publishing previously published data as original data. Copying without attribution is plagiarism under Standard 8.11. Beginning data collection before IRB approval violates Standard 8.01 (Institutional Approval), which requires approval before conducting research. A reviewer using a manuscript for personal gain violates Standard 8.15 (Reviewers), which requires reviewers to respect the confidentiality and proprietary rights of submitted materials.

questions.stem: For each type of research, select ALL specific ethical requirements that apply:

columns.text: May be exempt from individual informed consent
Must demonstrate non-deceptive alternatives are not feasible

questions.explanation: Deception research: Must provide debriefing (8.08), demonstrate non-deceptive alternatives aren't feasible (8.07), and requires IRB review. Archival research: May be exempt from individual informed consent if records are publicly available or de-identified (8.02), but still requires IRB determination. Student participant research: Must provide equitable alternative activities if participation is for course credit or required (8.04), and requires IRB review. All research with human participants requires IRB review or exemption determination.

questions.stem: For each Standard 8 provision, select ALL scenarios that would constitute a violation:

columns.text: A researcher omits unfavorable data from a published report
A lab director claims first authorship on all papers from their lab regardless of contribution
A researcher uses deception when non-deceptive alternatives would yield the same data
A researcher deceives participants about procedures that could cause severe emotional distress
A researcher runs additional analyses after initial results are non-significant without disclosing this

questions.explanation: Standard 8.10 violations: Omitting unfavorable data (col1) is selective reporting, and undisclosed post-hoc analyses (col5) misrepresent the analytic process. Standard 8.12 violation: Claiming authorship regardless of contribution (col2) violates the requirement that credit reflect relative contributions. Standard 8.07 violations: Using deception when alternatives exist (col3) fails the feasibility requirement, and deceiving about procedures causing severe distress (col4) is explicitly prohibited under 8.07(b).

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Standard 8 (Research and Publication):

Psychologists conducting research must obtain [BLANK1] approval before beginning data collection. Informed consent for research must include the [BLANK2], procedures, right to withdraw, and foreseeable risks. When deception is used, psychologists must demonstrate that [BLANK3] are not feasible and must provide [BLANK4] to participants as soon as feasible. Publication credit must reflect [BLANK5] to the work, regardless of the contributors' relative status.
questions.explanation: Standard 8 establishes: IRB approval is required before data collection (8.01). Informed consent includes purpose, procedures, right to withdraw, and risks (8.02). Deception requires demonstration that non-deceptive alternatives aren't feasible (8.07) and that debriefing occurs afterward (8.08). Publication credit is based on relative scientific contributions, not status or seniority (8.12).

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about research integrity under Standard 8:

Standard 8.10 requires that psychologists do not [BLANK1] data in their research reports. If psychologists discover significant errors in their published data, they must take reasonable steps to [BLANK2] the errors through appropriate means. Standard 8.11 prohibits [BLANK3], which involves presenting portions of another's work as one's own. Standard 8.13 prohibits [BLANK4], meaning psychologists do not publish previously published data as though it were original. Standard 8.14 requires psychologists to share research data for [BLANK5] by other competent professionals, subject to participant confidentiality protections.
questions.explanation: Standards 8.10 through 8.14 address research integrity: 8.10 prohibits data fabrication and requires correction of published errors. 8.11 prohibits plagiarism (presenting another's work as one's own). 8.13 prohibits duplicate publication (presenting previously published data as original). 8.14 requires data sharing for verification purposes while protecting participant confidentiality. Together, these standards form the foundation of scientific integrity in psychological research.

questions.stem: A psychology graduate student conducted most of the work for a research study, including literature review, data collection, analysis, and writing the manuscript. The faculty advisor provided the original idea and lab resources but had minimal involvement in the day-to-day execution. The faculty advisor now insists on being listed as first author.
questions.centerQuestion: Which ethical standard is most directly relevant?

options.text: The student conducted the majority of the scientific work
The student wrote the manuscript independently
Publication credit should reflect relative contributions, not status
The advisor provided the initial idea, which is the most important contribution
Discuss authorship based on documented relative contributions
The student should accept second authorship to avoid conflict
Consult departmental guidelines on authorship determination
Consider mediation through the department or ombudsperson if needed

questions.explanation: Standard 8.12 (Publication Credit) is directly relevant. It states that credit should reflect relative scientific or professional contributions regardless of status. The standard specifically notes that mere possession of an institutional position (e.g., department chair) does not justify authorship credit, and that minor contributions should be acknowledged in footnotes or an introductory statement. A student who did the majority of the work deserves primary authorship credit. Standard 8.12(b) specifically addresses student contributions to multi-authored publications based on dissertations.

questions.stem: A researcher is studying the effects of social exclusion on mood in college students. The study involves a computerized ball-tossing game (Cyberball) where participants are gradually excluded by the other players (who are actually computer-controlled). Participants are told they are playing with real people. After exclusion, many participants report feeling sad and rejected.
questions.centerQuestion: What is the primary ethical challenge in this study design?

options.text: The research question has significant scientific value for understanding social pain
Non-deceptive alternatives would not produce the same naturalistic emotional response
The deception is temporary and mild
Participants can simply choose not to feel excluded
IRB approval with specific attention to deception and emotional distress
Thorough debriefing explaining the true nature of the other 'players'
No debriefing needed since the distress is temporary
Availability of counseling services for participants who experience lasting distress

questions.explanation: Standard 8.07 (Deception in Research) is the primary challenge. The study deceives participants about the nature of the other players and creates a situation designed to induce negative emotional states. Justifications include significant scientific value and infeasibility of non-deceptive alternatives. Required safeguards include IRB approval, thorough debriefing (Standard 8.08), and access to counseling. Notably, 8.07(b) states psychologists must not deceive about research that is reasonably expected to cause physical pain or severe emotional distress.

questions.stem: A research ethics instructor is reviewing Standard 8 with students. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements about research ethics under the APA Ethics Code:
questions.passage: (A) Psychologists must obtain IRB approval or determination of exemption before beginning research with human participants. (B) Deception in research is always prohibited by the APA Ethics Code. (C) Research participants must be informed of their right to withdraw from a study at any time without penalty. (D) Publication credit should be determined solely by seniority within the research team. (E) When research participation is required for a course, students must be given equitable alternative activities. (F) Psychologists who discover significant errors in their published data must take reasonable steps to correct them. (G) Researchers may dispose of original data immediately after publication to protect participant privacy. (H) Informed consent for research requires only verbal agreement; written consent is never necessary.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) IRB approval/exemption required (8.01); (C) Right to withdraw without penalty (8.02); (E) Equitable alternatives for required participation (8.04); (F) Obligation to correct published errors (8.10). Incorrect: (B) Deception is permitted under specific conditions (8.07); (D) Credit reflects contributions, not seniority (8.12); (G) Data must be retained for verification (8.14); (H) Written consent is often required by IRBs and some situations clearly require documentation.

questions.stem: A graduate research methods instructor is preparing exam review materials on research integrity. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements about Standards 8.10 through 8.15:
questions.passage: (A) Standard 8.10 requires psychologists to take reasonable steps to correct significant errors discovered in their published data, such as through errata, corrections, or retractions. (B) Standard 8.11 permits psychologists to present portions of another's work or data as their own as long as the original source is publicly available. (C) Standard 8.12 requires that principal authorship reflect the relative scientific or professional contributions of the individuals involved, regardless of their relative status. (D) Standard 8.13 permits psychologists to publish previously published data in a new journal as long as it is reformatted and uses a different title. (E) Standard 8.14 requires psychologists to share research data for verification by other competent professionals who seek to verify substantive claims through reanalysis. (F) Standard 8.15 requires that psychologists who review material submitted for publication respect the confidentiality of and proprietary rights in such information. (G) Under Standard 8.12, a department chairperson who provides lab space and administrative support automatically deserves first authorship. (H) Standard 8.14 allows researchers to permanently refuse all data sharing requests to protect their competitive advantage.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Standard 8.10(b) requires error correction; (C) Standard 8.12 bases authorship on contributions, not status; (E) Standard 8.14 requires data sharing for verification; (F) Standard 8.15 protects confidentiality of reviewed manuscripts. Incorrect: (B) Presenting another's work as one's own is plagiarism (8.11); (D) Republishing without disclosure is duplicate publication (8.13); (G) Administrative support alone does not warrant authorship (8.12); (H) Competitive advantage is not a legitimate basis for refusing verification requests (8.14).

questions.stem: Arrange the steps of the ethical research process in the correct sequence:

options.text: Collect data from participants
Design study and prepare IRB application
Provide debriefing to participants (especially if deception was used)
Obtain IRB approval or exemption determination
Obtain informed consent from each participant

questions.explanation: The ethical research sequence: Design the study and prepare the IRB application, ensuring all ethical concerns are addressed. Obtain IRB approval before any contact with participants (Standard 8.01). Obtain informed consent from each participant (Standard 8.02). Collect data according to the approved protocol. Provide debriefing as soon as feasible after participation (Standard 8.08). Each step must be completed before proceeding to the next.

questions.stem: Arrange the hierarchy of authorship considerations from most to least important according to Standard 8.12:

options.text: Faculty status or seniority within the department
Relative scientific or professional contribution to the work
Role in securing funding for the research
Providing the original research idea
Conducting the majority of data collection and analysis

questions.explanation: Standard 8.12 prioritizes relative scientific contributions over all other factors. Conducting the majority of the actual work (data collection, analysis) is a substantial contribution. Providing the original idea is important but less weight if minimal subsequent involvement. Securing funding is administrative. Faculty status/seniority should have no bearing on authorship determination. The standard explicitly states that institutional position does not justify authorship credit.

questions.stem: Review data on research ethics complaints filed with a university IRB over a 10-year period:

questions.question: What is the most notable trend across the 10-year period?

options.text: All categories of complaints are decreasing
Online/digital research ethics issues have become the dominant complaint category
Deception complaints are increasing
Informed consent issues remain the most common complaint throughout

questions.question: What likely explains the increase in online/digital research ethics issues?

options.text: The APA Ethics Code has changed to prohibit online research
Growth of online data collection, social media research, and big data raises novel ethical challenges
Researchers are deliberately ignoring online ethics
Online research does not require ethical oversight

questions.explanation: The data show a dramatic shift: traditional issues (informed consent, deception/debriefing) have decreased while online/digital research ethics issues have surged. This reflects the growth of online data collection, social media research, MTurk/Prolific studies, and big data analytics, which raise novel questions about consent (can clicking 'agree' constitute informed consent?), privacy (is public social media data 'public'?), and debriefing (how to debrief anonymous online participants).

questions.stem: A graduate program tracks authorship dispute resolution outcomes over several cohorts:

questions.question: What does the trend suggest about the program's efforts to address authorship ethics?

options.text: The program has been ineffective at addressing authorship disputes
Early and clear communication about authorship expectations has reduced the need for formal intervention
Students are simply accepting unfair authorship arrangements
Authorship disputes have increased over time

questions.question: What programmatic change likely contributed to the increase in disputes resolved by discussion?

options.text: Eliminating authorship requirements entirely
Implementing authorship agreements at the start of research collaborations
Giving faculty unilateral authorship decisions
Removing students from publication processes

questions.explanation: The positive trend shows increasingly effective dispute resolution: more disputes resolved by simple discussion and fewer requiring mediation or formal complaints. This likely reflects programmatic changes such as implementing authorship agreements at the outset of collaborations (consistent with Standard 8.12's emphasis on upfront discussion of contributions), better training in research ethics, and clearer departmental guidelines about contribution-based authorship.

questions.stem: Categorize each research practice according to whether it is ethically acceptable or a violation under Standard 8:

items.text: Using deception when non-deceptive alternatives exist that could address the research question
Offering course credit with equitable alternatives for non-participants
Fabricating data to fill in missing values in a dataset
Providing debriefing that explains the true purpose of a deception study
Listing a contributor as second author when their contribution was providing lab space only
Obtaining informed consent that includes right to withdraw without penalty

questions.explanation: Acceptable: Offering credit with alternatives (8.04b), providing debriefing after deception (8.08), obtaining complete informed consent (8.02). Violations: Using deception when alternatives exist (8.07 requires demonstrating non-deceptive alternatives are not feasible), fabricating data (8.10 prohibits fabrication), granting authorship for minimal contribution like lab space alone (8.12 requires substantive scientific contribution for authorship).

questions.stem: Categorize each situation according to which Standard 8 provision is most directly relevant:

items.text: A researcher explains the study purpose, risks, and right to withdraw before beginning data collection
A researcher reveals the true purpose of a study to participants after they complete the experimental protocol
A researcher discovers a coding error that changed the significance of published results and issues an erratum
A researcher submits the same manuscript to two journals simultaneously without disclosure
A researcher explains to participants that their data will be kept confidential and stored securely
A researcher corrects participants' false beliefs about the study that resulted from the use of a cover story

questions.explanation: Standard 8.02 (Informed Consent): Explaining study purpose, risks, and right to withdraw (item1) and discussing confidentiality protections (item5) are core informed consent elements. Standard 8.07/8.08 (Deception/Debriefing): Revealing the true purpose after the study (item2) and correcting misconceptions from cover stories (item6) are debriefing obligations. Standard 8.10-8.14 (Reporting/Publication): Issuing an erratum for a coding error (item3, Standard 8.10) and dual journal submission (item4, Standard 8.13) address publication integrity.
